review.title: Derivative Delay Embedding: Online Modeling of Streaming Time Series
review.abstract: The staggering amount of streaming time series coming from the real world calls for more efficient and effective online modeling solution. For time series modeling, most existing works make some unrealistic assumptions such as the input data is of fixed length or well aligned, which requires extra effort on segmentation or normalization of the raw streaming data. Although some literature claim their approaches to be invariant to data length and misalignment, they are too time-consuming to model a streaming time series in an online manner. We propose a novel and more practical online modeling and classification scheme, DDE-MGM, which does not make any assumptions on the time series while maintaining high efficiency and state-of-the-art performance. The derivative delay embedding (DDE) is developed to incrementally transform time series to the embedding space, where the intrinsic characteristics of data is preserved as recursive patterns regardless of the stream length and misalignment. Then, a non-parametric Markov geographic model (MGM) is proposed to both model and classify the pattern in an online manner. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and superior classification accuracy of the proposed DDE-MGM in an online setting as compared to the state-of-the-art.
histories: Accepted by The 25th ACM International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management (CIKM 2016)
review.COMMENTS: Accepted by The 25th ACM International Conference on Information and Knowledge Management (CIKM 2016)

metadata.title: Derivative Delay Embedding: Online Modeling of Streaming Time Series

sections.text: Tags Delay Embedding; Streaming Time Series; Online Modelling and Classification; Markov Geographical ModelSource: https: / / github.com / ZZUTK / Delay Embedding.git

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: There has been an unprecedented increase in interest in streaming time series modeling and classification, mainly due to the rapid deployment of smart devices. Traditionally, time series classification has been performed using an offline training process coupled with an online / offline classification process. During the training process, some pre-processing steps are normally performed, including segmentation of time series into finite (usually specified) length and alignment of segments to facilitate subsequent functional extraction, which usually produces discriminatory patterns for classification purposes. However, with the explosion of the smart device and the associated jump in traffic, new challenges in time series analysis arise. For example, time series data typically exhibit time-varying features over an, in theory, infinite time span, so the time series is manually shortened to fixed length, well-aligned segments run the risk of requiring some intrinsic characteristics of the classification side to many of the fictional responses.

sections.heading: 1.1 Motivation
sections.text: The theory of deceleration embedding [24, 22] was first introduced to reconstruct a chaotic dynamic system from a sequence of observations of the system.The reconstruction preserves the coordinate and period changes of the dynamic system, but it is invariant against phase changes (i.e. misalignment).Another advantage of deceleration embedding is its low computational complexity, such as O (1).In addition, the reconstruction is performed step by step, which facilitates online processing, since only more recent observations are taken into account when the dynamic system is reconstructed from a flowing time series.The reconstructed dynamic system is usually presented in a higher dimensional space, in which the dynamics exhibit recursive patterns [8, 18, 9] regardless of the length of the dynamic time series, which is altered by a potentially finite time shift.

sections.heading: 1.2 Related Work
sections.text: The dynamic pastime (DTW) method [2] has achieved good performance in the time series classification, especially in the time from 1: 1 to 2: 2. DTW-based methods usually suffer from high computer complexity, which is not suitable for many real-time applications. However, they have limited the high computer complexity in training and the need to make the two impractical assumptions, i.e., the decision tree [21], the neural network [6].

sections.heading: 2. DERIVATIVE DELAY EMBEDDING
sections.text: In this section we first present the background of the delay embedding, then the proposed derivative delay embedding (DDE) and its invariant property on data length and misalignment are explained, and finally the parameter selection for delay embedding and DDE is discussed to facilitate the application of DDE in the real world.

sections.heading: 2.2 Derivative Delay Embedding
sections.text: Although the embedding delay is robust to the length and phase changes of the time series, as shown above, it is sensitive to the shifting of the baseline. For example, the zero drift effect will cause the sensor output to drift even though the external environment has not changed at all; or different types of sensors monitoring the same variable may yield results in different baselines. Furthermore, embedding the room requires continuous space, so the exact position of the states / trajectory would consume large storage capacities. To address these two issues, we are developing the Derived Embedding Delay (DDE) method, which uses the observation function (xt) = y ² t to shift the baseline shift, and then discredit embedding the room into a grid to reduce storage costs.

sections.heading: 2.3 Parameter Selection
sections.text: There are two parameters in the delay, i.e., the delay stage s and the embedding dimension d. empirical studies show that d and s both significantly influence the performance of embedding in the aspect of classification accuracy, and they are application-oriented, varying with different datasets. In DDE we have an additional parameter - the cell size of the discredited embedding space, which determines the accuracy of the representation of state development. This section discusses the methods of selecting suitable values for s, d, and the grid size.2.1 Delay Step (s) According to [17], an effective method of observing the optimal s is to minimize the mutual information between yt and yt + s. The idea is to ensure a sufficiently large quantity so that the information measured at t + s differs significantly from the time.

sections.heading: 3. MARKOV GEOGRAPHIC MODEL
sections.text: As discussed in the DDE, the trajectory constructed from a time series will preserve distinct and robust patterns. Therefore, we can model the trajectories of different classes during training, and then the label of a test time series could be decided by comparison with the trajectories learned. However, many existing work related to the delay of embedding would model the trajectories through a group of differential functions, parametric models, or topological features [18], such as barcodes from persistent homology. However, they all perform in one way, and it is difficult to find a parametric model that is suitable for all applications. We propose a non-parametric model MGM that could model the trajectories in an online maneuver.From Fig. 1, we can see that the trajectory and geographical location of states both carry significant information that distinguish one pattern from another.

sections.heading: 4. ONLINE MODELING
sections.text: Figure 7 shows the sequence of the DDE-MGM scheme, assuming for simplicity d = 2 and s = 1. In online modeling, a training time series flows through a buffer of size (d − 1) s + 1 = 2. When a new data point arrives, the oldest one is removed from the buffer, and only the data points in the buffer are applied to DDE to construct a state in the discredited embedding space. State location and transition from the previous state are updated in the corresponding MGM.

sections.heading: 4.1 Representing MGM
sections.text: For example, in a discretized embedding space of 50 x 50 raster, the geographic distribution requires 502 bytes to record the number of states falling into each cell (| Φ ′ (xt) | in Eq.10). For the transition probability, it is a common method to capture all possible transitions, to construct a (50 x 50) 2 matrix that is huge and a waste of memory. As such a matrix is usually sparse, we use a "list" to accumulate only these active transitions (| Φ ′ (xt); Φ ′ (xt − 1) | in Eq.11). Note that each class maintains its own MGM. The modeling process transforms the time series and updates MGMs in real time without any pre-processing or assumptions about the time series. During the classification, a test stream is also transformed into the embedding space where Eq.12 can be applied to calculate the similarity between each class S · S (M) and each S = S (M) step by step.

sections.heading: 5. EXPERIMENTAL EVALUATION
sections.text: The proposed DDE-MGM is evaluated on the basis of three sets of data - UCI character trajectories [12], MSR Action3D [26] and PAMAP [20] outdoor activities. To illustrate the low computational complexity and superior classification power, DDE-MGM is compared with HMM [15], SAX [13] and 1NNDTW [29], which are considered to be the best algorithms for classifying time series. In addition, we also compare with some state-of-the-art online algorithms, RBP [4], Projectron [16], BPAS [27], BOGD [31] and NOGD [14] to verify the online performance of DDE-MGM. Besides classification accuracy, it is also about evaluating the computational complexity.

sections.heading: 5.1 Datasets
sections.text: The UCI Character Trajectory dataset [12] consists of 2858 character samples from 20 classes. Three dimensions are maintained - x, y and peak force. Data has been normalized and shifted so that their velocity profiles best match the mean of the set. This dataset serves as a starting point for comparing different algorithms, as its samples are well aligned, shortened to the same length and normalized to the same baseline. The MSR Action3D dataset [26] is the most popular dataset used by most action-related literature. It consists of 567 action samples from 20 classes performed by 10 subjects. This dataset is of random data length with no careful alignment. Each action sample is represented by a sequence of skeletons with 20 joints in 3-D space, the spatial accuracy of the data being considered a 60-D time series, as each skeleton is considered a point of 20 (x) (3) joints.

sections.heading: 5.2 Experimental Setup
sections.text: In DDE-MGM there are a total of four parameters - s, d and grid size for DDE (Eq. 6) and r for the neighbourhood comparison function (Eqs. 12 and 16). Parameters s and d can be determined by applying Eqs. 8 and 9 (false nearest neighbour) to randomly selected training samples and then selecting the averaged settings. In the experiment, two groups of algorithms are cited to compare them with the proposed DDE-MGM: 1) Offline algorithms that can achieve the state-of-the-art classification are specified as cell size. the neighbouring size r is supposed to be the cell size.In the experiment, two groups of algorithms are cited to compare with the proposed DDE-MGM: 1) Offline algorithms that can achieve the first-class classification accuracy can achieve the first-class technical accuracy, but it is time consuming or assuming that the input data are of the same length and alignment.

sections.heading: 5.3 Classification Performance
sections.text: In fact, it is the case that most of them are able to move into another world, in which they are able to move, in which they move, in which they move, in which they move, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they, in which they live, in which they live, in which they, in which they live.

sections.heading: 5.4 How Fast is DDE-MGM Model?
sections.text: We have stated that DDE-MGM can achieve online modeling. However, no online method can handle a time series with an infinite streaming rate. So, what is the limit of DDEMGM? To find the limit, we use the PAMAP datasets again, because their long duration is suitable to investigate the maximum modeling speed. In the modeling phase of DDE-MGM there are altogether three parameters - delay step s, embedding dimension d and the cell size of the discredited embedding space. The parameters d and s determine how many points and which intervals they extract from the data stream in order to reconstruct a state in the embedding space. Variation of these parameters will not affect the computer-related complexity of the DDE, whose runtime is approximately constant.

sections.heading: 5.5 Effect of Parameter Setting
sections.text: Although appropriate parameter settings for the deceleration step s and the embedding of dimension d can be achieved using the methods in [18] and [8], it is still interesting to see the effects of the two parameters on classification accuracy. This section compares the accuracy using different s or d on the UCI drawing curves and MSR Action3D datasets. Fig. 11 shows the effect of s on classification accuracy. Fig. 11 (a) shows that the s selected in our experiment based on the method in [18] are not necessarily the best s, because the accuracy is slightly higher at s = 12 (92.21%). However, the accuracy of the selected s is very close to the optimum s. For the same reason, the selected d is not necessarily the best, as in Fig. 12.In particular, both s and d significantly affect classification accuracy.

sections.heading: 6. CONCLUSIONS
sections.text: In this paper, we proposed a new method, DDE-MGM, to model and classify time series online, completely removing common but unrealistic assumptions such as the same data length and alignment, facilitating the use of the method for solving problems in the real world. DDE-MGM's main goal is to achieve computational efficiency in terms of both computing time and memory consumption, while maintaining superior classification accuracy compared to the most modern methods. Experiments conducted on three real data sets had (1) confirmed the effectiveness of using the web in the embedding space to distinguish the intrinsic patterns of different classes in the training steam of the time domain, (2) the flexibility and feasibility of the novel online processing program for data flows without assumptions, (3) the great potential for real-time modelling and classification, and (4) the small and constant storage requirements.

metadata.abstractText: The staggering amount of streaming time series coming from the real world calls for more efficient and effective online modeling solution. For time series modeling, most existing works make some unrealistic assumptions such as the input data is of fixed length or well aligned, which requires extra effort on segmentation or normalization of the raw streaming data. Although some literature claim their approaches to be invariant to data length and misalignment, they are too time-consuming to model a streaming time series in an online manner. We propose a novel and more practical online modeling and classification scheme, DDE-MGM, which does not make any assumptions on the time series while maintaining high efficiency and state-of-the-art performance. The derivative delay embedding (DDE) is developed to incrementally transform time series to the embedding space, where the intrinsic characteristics of data is preserved as recursive patterns regardless of the stream length and misalignment. Then, a non-parametric Markov geographic model (MGM) is proposed to both model and classify the pattern in an online manner. Experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness and superior classification accuracy of the proposed DDE-MGM in an online setting as compared to the stateof-the-art.
